The final semester emphasizes practical applications and contemporary issues in financial management.

Strategic Financial Management: Integration of financial strategy with overall business strategy.

Financial Modeling: Techniques for creating financial models to forecast and analyze financial performance.

Corporate Valuation: Methods for valuing a business, including discounted cash flow analysis and comparables.

Capstone Project: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world financial management challenges.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Financial Modeling” by Simon Benninga.

“Valuation: Measuring and Managing the Value of Companies” by McKinsey & Company Inc.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

CFA Institute (for strategic financial management)

WallStreetMojo (for corporate valuation techniques)

Back

Human Resource Management

This course focuses on the strategic approach to managing an organization's most valuable asset—its people. It covers the essential aspects of recruiting, training, performance management, and employee relations.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of human resource management.

Introduction to Human Resource Management: Overview of HRM, its significance in organizations, and the role of HR professionals.

Organizational Behavior: Understanding individual and group behavior within organizations and its impact on performance.

Recruitment and Selection: Techniques and strategies for attracting, selecting, and onboarding talent.

Training and Development: Importance of employee training, development programs, and career planning.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Human Resource Management” by Gary Dessler.

“Managing Human Resources” by Luis R. Gomez-Mejia, David B. Balkin, and Robert L. Cardy.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) (for foundational HR concepts)

HR 360 (for recruitment strategies)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves into essential HR functions and practices.

Performance Management: Strategies for assessing and enhancing employee performance through feedback and appraisal systems.

Compensation and Benefits: Understanding compensation structures, benefits administration, and employee rewards.

Employee Relations: Strategies for managing employee relations, conflict resolution, and labor laws.

Diversity and Inclusion: Importance of fostering a diverse workplace and creating an inclusive culture.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Performance Management: Key Strategies and Techniques” by Michael Armstrong.

“Compensation” by George T. Milkovich and Jerry M. Newman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

HRM Training (for performance management techniques)

TED Talks (for diversity and inclusion discussions)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers advanced topics in human resource management.

Strategic Human Resource Management: Aligning HR strategies with organizational goals and objectives.

Change Management: Understanding the processes involved in organizational change and the role of HR in facilitating change.

Labor Relations: Study of labor unions, collective bargaining, and dispute resolution.

HR Analytics: Leveraging data and analytics to drive HR decisions and improve organizational performance.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Strategic Human Resource Management” by Jeffrey A. Mello.

“Change Management: The People Side of Change” by John P. Kotter.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

HR University (for strategic HR management)

HR Analytics (for HR analytics techniques)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes practical applications and current trends in human resource management.

Global Human Resource Management: Understanding HR practices in a global context and managing a diverse workforce.

HR Technology: Exploration of HR information systems (HRIS) and technology's role in HR processes.

Capstone Project: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world HR challenges.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Global Human Resource Management” by J. Brian Houston.

“HR Technology: How to Apply the Technology to Your Business” by Tracie S. C. Murray.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

HR Happy Hour (for global HR practices)

CIPD (for HR technology discussions)

Back

Urban Management

This course focuses on the principles and practices of managing urban areas, emphasizing sustainable development, policy formulation, and urban governance.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of urban management.

Introduction to Urban Management: Overview of urban management concepts, challenges, and significance in contemporary society.

Urban Planning and Development: Principles of urban planning, land use, zoning, and the development process.

Urban Governance: Understanding governance structures, policies, and the role of stakeholders in urban areas.

Sustainable Urban Development: Exploring sustainability principles and practices in urban settings.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Urban Management: Theory and Practice” by J. D. Tewari.

“The Urban Revolution” by Henri Lefebvre.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Planetizen (for urban planning concepts)

Sustainable Cities (for sustainable urban development)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers essential aspects of urban management practices.

Urban Economics: Understanding the economic aspects of urban areas, including land value, real estate, and urban finance.

Transport and Mobility Management: Strategies for managing transportation systems and enhancing urban mobility.

Environmental Management in Urban Areas: Addressing environmental issues and challenges in urban settings.

Community Development: Exploring community engagement, participation, and development strategies.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Urban Economics” by Arthur O'Sullivan.

“Community Development: Theory and Practice” by Margaret Ledwith.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Urban Policy Lab (for urban economics)

World Bank (for community development initiatives)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes advanced topics in urban management.

Urban Health and Wellbeing: Exploring the relationship between urban environments and public health.

Urban Risk Management: Understanding risks in urban areas, including natural disasters and climate change.

Smart Cities and Technology: The role of technology in urban management and the development of smart cities.

Urban Policy Analysis: Techniques for analyzing urban policies and their impacts.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Urban Health: Global Perspectives” by S. A. C. Tiwari.

“Smart Cities: A Spatialised Intelligence” by Michael Batty.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Smart Cities World (for smart city concepts)

The Urban Institute (for urban policy analysis)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on practical applications and contemporary trends in urban management.

Urban Management Capstone Project: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world urban management challenges.

Policy Formulation and Implementation: Understanding the process of creating and implementing urban policies.

Global Urban Challenges: Addressing global issues such as migration, urban poverty, and inequality.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Urban Policy and Research” by Greg Clark.

“Cities and Urban Life” by John Macionis and Vincent Parrillo.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

International Urban Planning (for global urban challenges)

MIT Urban Studies (for urban management practices)

Back

Policy Evaluation

This course focuses on the principles and practices of evaluating public policies, emphasizing effectiveness, efficiency, and impact assessment.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts of policy evaluation.

Introduction to Policy Evaluation: Overview of the importance of evaluation in the policy-making process.

Evaluation Frameworks: Understanding various frameworks and methodologies for conducting evaluations.

Data Collection Methods: Techniques for collecting qualitative and quantitative data in policy evaluation.

Ethics in Policy Evaluation: Exploring ethical considerations in the evaluation process.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Evaluation Theory, Models, and Applications” by Daniel Stufflebeam and Chris L. S. Shinkfield.

“The Handbook of Public Policy Evaluation” by Stuart S. Nagel.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Policy Analysis (for introduction to policy evaluation)

Research Methods (for data collection techniques)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers advanced topics in policy evaluation.

Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis: Analyzing data using qualitative and quantitative methods.

Impact Assessment: Techniques for assessing the impact of public policies on various stakeholders.

Cost-Benefit Analysis: Understanding the principles of cost-benefit analysis in policy evaluation.

Case Studies in Policy Evaluation: Reviewing real-world case studies to understand evaluation practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Cost-Benefit Analysis: Concepts and Practice” by Anthony E. Boardman et al.

“Using Case Studies in Research” by Jennifer A. C. Murphy.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Evaluation Resources (for qualitative and quantitative analysis)

Impact Assessment (for impact assessment techniques)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes practical applications of policy evaluation.

Evaluation Design: Designing effective evaluation studies and selecting appropriate methodologies.

Reporting and Communicating Findings: Best practices for reporting evaluation findings to stakeholders.

Policy Relevance and Utilization: Ensuring that evaluation results are relevant and utilized in policy-making.

Current Trends in Policy Evaluation: Exploring emerging trends and innovations in the field of policy evaluation.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Evaluation Design: A Self-Instructional Guide” by Thomas D. Cook and William R. Shadish.

“The Evaluation Gap: A Resource Guide” by David W. Derryberry.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Public Policy (for evaluation design)

Evidence Based Policy (for reporting findings)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on practical applications and contemporary issues in policy evaluation.

Capstone Project in Policy Evaluation: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world policy evaluation challenges.

Policy Evaluation in Different Sectors: Evaluating policies in sectors such as education, health, and environment.

Future Directions in Policy Evaluation: Discussing future trends and challenges in the field of policy evaluation.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Public Policy: An Introduction to the Theory and Practice of Policy Analysis” by David L. Weimer and Aidan R. Vining.

“Evaluating Public Policy” by William N. Dunn.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Global Policy Evaluation (for policy evaluation in different sectors)

Future of Evaluation (for future directions)

Future Paths

  • Policy Analyst: Analyzing and evaluating public policies to inform decision-making.
  • Program Evaluator: Assessing the effectiveness and impact of various programs and initiatives.
  • Research Consultant: Conducting research and providing insights on policy-related issues.
  • Public Affairs Specialist: Communicating policy evaluation findings to stakeholders and the public.
  • Non-Profit Sector Evaluator: Evaluating programs and policies in non-profit organizations.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in public policy or evaluation organizations.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in the field of policy evaluation through events and seminars.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on policy trends and evaluation methods through news sources and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on policy evaluation and related methodologies to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to public policy and evaluation for resources and support.
Back

International Public Management

This course explores the management of public organizations at the international level, emphasizing global governance, policy implementation, and collaborative management across borders.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces foundational concepts in international public management.

Introduction to International Public Management: Overview of the role and importance of public management in an international context.

Global Governance: Understanding the frameworks and institutions that govern international relations.

International Policy Implementation: Strategies and challenges in implementing policies across different countries.

Comparative Public Administration: Analyzing public administration systems and practices in various countries.

Recommended Reference Books:

“International Public Management: Policy and Practice” by Michael J. Sullivan.

“Comparative Public Administration” by John D. Stephens.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

International Relations (for an introduction to global governance)

Public Management (for international policy implementation)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers advanced topics in international public management.

Managing International Organizations: Understanding the management structures and practices within international organizations.

Cross-Cultural Management: Exploring the impact of cultural differences on public management practices.

Global Public Policy: Examining public policies that have international implications.

Public Sector Innovation: Strategies for fostering innovation in the public sector at the global level.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Managing International Organizations” by Paul J. DiMaggio.

“Cultural Intelligence: Surviving and Thriving in the Global Village” by David C. Thomas and Mark F. Peterson.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Global Public Policy (for managing international organizations)

Cross Cultural Management (for cross-cultural management insights)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes practical applications in international public management.

Strategic Management in International Contexts: Developing strategic management skills for international public organizations.

Policy Analysis and Evaluation: Techniques for analyzing and evaluating international public policies.

Public Financial Management: Understanding financial management practices in international public organizations.

Human Resources Management in the Global Context: Managing human resources in international organizations.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Strategic Management in the Public Sector” by Alan M. McCarthy.

“Public Financial Management” by Andrew Graham.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Strategic Management (for strategic management in international contexts)

Public Financial Management (for public financial management insights)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on contemporary issues and challenges in international public management.

Global Crisis Management: Understanding the management of crises at the international level.

Digital Governance: Exploring the impact of digital technologies on public management practices.

Capstone Project in International Public Management: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world challenges in international public management.

Future Trends in Public Management: Discussing emerging trends and challenges in the field of international public management.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Crisis Management in the Digital Age” by Steven Fink.

“Digital Governance: New Technologies for Improving Public Service and Participation” by Ganesh P. V. Sharma.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Crisis Management (for global crisis management insights)

Digital Governance (for digital governance trends)

Future Paths

  • International Public Manager: Managing public organizations and initiatives at the international level.
  • Policy Analyst: Analyzing and developing policies with international implications.
  • Global Governance Specialist: Working with international organizations to implement policies and programs.
  • Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) Manager: Overseeing projects and programs for international NGOs.
  • Consultant for International Development: Advising governments and organizations on public management practices.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in international organizations or NGOs.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in international public management through events and conferences.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on global governance trends and management practices through news sources and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on international public management to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to public management for resources and support.
Back

Crisis Management

This course focuses on the strategies and practices for managing crises in various sectors, emphasizing preparation, response, and recovery from critical situations.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces foundational concepts and frameworks in crisis management.

Introduction to Crisis Management: Overview of the principles and theories related to crisis management.

Crisis Communication: Understanding the importance of effective communication during a crisis.

Risk Assessment and Management: Techniques for identifying and managing potential risks that could lead to crises.

Legal and Ethical Issues in Crisis Management: Exploring the legal frameworks and ethical considerations in crisis situations.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Crisis Management: Planning for the Inevitable” by Steven Fink.

“The New Disaster Handbook” by Michael J. O’Connor.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Crisis Management (for an introduction to crisis management)

Risk Management (for insights into risk assessment)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers advanced topics and case studies in crisis management.

Emergency Preparedness: Planning and preparing for various types of emergencies and crises.

Business Continuity Management: Strategies to ensure organizational resilience during crises.

Public Health Crisis Management: Managing crises related to public health, including pandemics.

Technological Crises: Understanding crises caused by technological failures or cybersecurity threats.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Emergency Management: Principles and Practice for Local Government” by Thomas E. Drabek.

“The Handbook of Crisis Communication” by W. Timothy Coombs.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Emergency Management (for emergency preparedness)

Public Health Crisis (for public health crisis management)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes practical applications and real-world scenarios in crisis management.

Crisis Simulation and Drills: Conducting simulations to prepare for various crisis scenarios.

Post-Crisis Recovery: Strategies for recovery and learning from crises.

Crisis Leadership and Team Management: Leading teams during crises and managing crisis response.

International Perspectives on Crisis Management: Examining crisis management practices in a global context.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Leadership in Crises: The Power of Human Connection” by Michael A. Hynes.

“Crisis Management: Master the Skills to Prevent Disasters” by Michael J. Smith.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Crisis Simulation (for crisis simulation techniques)

Crisis Leadership (for leadership in crisis situations)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on emerging trends and the future of crisis management.

Social Media and Crisis Management: Utilizing social media in crisis communication and management.

Global Crises and Responses: Analyzing recent global crises and lessons learned.

Capstone Project in Crisis Management: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world crisis scenarios.

Future Trends in Crisis Management: Discussing the future of crisis management in an evolving landscape.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Social Media for Crisis Communication” by Anna B. K. M. Liu.

“Crisis Management: A Casebook Approach” by A. Timothy L. Smith.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Social Media Crisis (for using social media in crisis)

Global Crisis (for insights into global crises)

Future Paths

  • Crisis Management Consultant: Advising organizations on crisis preparedness and response strategies.
  • Emergency Management Director: Leading emergency management efforts within government agencies or NGOs.
  • Risk Management Specialist: Assessing and managing risks for organizations.
  • Public Relations Officer: Managing communication strategies during crises.
  • Business Continuity Planner: Developing plans to ensure business continuity during disruptions.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in emergency management or public relations.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in crisis management through events and seminars.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on crisis management trends and best practices through news sources and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on crisis management to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to crisis management for resources and support.
Back

Public Finance

This course focuses on the role of the government in the economy, including taxation, government expenditure, budgeting, and public debt management.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of public finance, emphasizing theoretical frameworks and concepts.

Introduction to Public Finance: Overview of public finance and its significance in the economy.

Public Revenue: Study of government revenue sources, including taxes and non-tax revenues.

Public Expenditure: Analysis of government spending and its impact on economic development.

Fiscal Policy: Understanding fiscal policy tools and their effects on the economy.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Public Finance” by Harvey S. Rosen and Ted Gayer.

“Public Finance: A Contemporary Application of Theory to Policy” by David N. Hyman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Public Finance Channel (for introductions to public finance concepts)

Fiscal Policy Expert (for insights into fiscal policy)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester covers more advanced topics in public finance and their real-world applications.

Taxation Theory and Practice: Exploring the principles and practices of taxation, including equity and efficiency.

Public Debt Management: Understanding government borrowing, debt sustainability, and implications for the economy.

Public Budgeting: Study of the budgeting process, budget types, and performance measurement.

Economic Analysis of Public Policy: Applying economic theories to evaluate public policies.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Taxation: Theory and Practice” by John G. Head.

“Public Budgeting Systems” by Robert D. Lee Jr., Ronald W. Johnson, and Philip G. Joyce.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Taxation Theory (for in-depth discussions on taxation)

Public Budgeting (for budgeting processes and practices)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes the analysis and evaluation of public finance policies.

Public Finance in Developing Countries: Analyzing public finance issues in developing nations.

Intergovernmental Fiscal Relations: Understanding the financial relationships between different levels of government.

Public Sector Economics: Examining the economic roles of the public sector and its impact on the economy.

Public Financial Management: Strategies for effective management of public financial resources.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Public Finance in Developing Countries” by Richard M. Bird and Eric M. Zolt.

“Public Sector Economics” by A. M. P. O. Palda.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Public Finance in Developing (for discussions on finance in developing countries)

Public Sector Economics (for insights into public sector roles)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on the contemporary issues and future directions in public finance.

Public Finance and the Environment: Exploring the intersection of public finance and environmental policy.

Globalization and Public Finance: Analyzing how globalization affects public finance.

Capstone Project in Public Finance: A practical project where students apply their knowledge to real-world public finance issues.

Emerging Trends in Public Finance: Discussing recent developments and innovations in public finance practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Public Finance and the Environment” by A. Myrick Freeman III.

“Globalization and Public Finance” by A. P. Thiruvengadam.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Public Finance and the Environment (for discussions on environmental policies)

Globalization and Public Finance (for globalization's impact on public finance)

Future Paths

  • Public Finance Consultant: Advising governments and organizations on public finance matters.
  • Tax Policy Analyst: Analyzing and developing tax policies for governments or think tanks.
  • Budget Analyst: Managing and analyzing government budgets.
  • Public Policy Advisor: Advising on public policy issues related to finance.
  • Economic Development Specialist: Working on public finance strategies to promote economic growth.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in government finance departments or NGOs.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in public finance through events and seminars.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on public finance trends and regulations through news sources and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on public finance to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to public finance for resources and support.
Back

E-Governance

This course focuses on the integration of information technology in government processes, aiming to improve service delivery, enhance transparency, and foster citizen engagement.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts of e-governance and its importance in modern governance.

Introduction to E-Governance: Overview of e-governance, its principles, and significance.

Digital Government: Examining the transition from traditional governance to digital governance.

Information and Communication Technology (ICT) in Governance: Role of ICT in enhancing government services.

CITIZEN-CENTRIC E-Governance: Strategies for improving citizen engagement through technology.

Recommended Reference Books:

“E-Governance: Concepts and Case Studies” by K. Ramesh.

“Digital Government: Technology and Public Sector Performance” by Michael J. Ahn and Victor C. Smith.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

E-Governance Channel (for foundational e-governance concepts)

Digital Government (for insights on digital transformation in government)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on the implementation of e-governance projects and their impact on public administration.

E-Governance Frameworks and Models: Understanding various frameworks for implementing e-governance.

Project Management for E-Governance: Techniques for managing e-governance projects effectively.

Data Management in E-Governance: Best practices for handling data in government systems.

Cybersecurity in E-Governance: Addressing security challenges in digital governance.

Recommended Reference Books:

“E-Governance in India: Challenges and Opportunities” by S. R. Ranjan.

“E-Governance: Issues and Challenges” by S. Chand.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

E-Governance Implementation (for project management in e-governance)

Cyber Security Governance (for cybersecurity in governance)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester emphasizes evaluation, assessment, and the impact of e-governance initiatives.

Evaluation of E-Governance Projects: Techniques for assessing the effectiveness of e-governance initiatives.

Impact of E-Governance on Public Service Delivery: Analyzing the changes in service delivery due to e-governance.

Legal and Ethical Aspects of E-Governance: Understanding legal frameworks and ethical issues in digital governance.

Innovation in E-Governance: Exploring new trends and technologies in governance.

Recommended Reference Books:

“E-Governance: A Global Perspective” by R. B. Dutta.

“E-Government: Information Technology and Transformational Government” by A. A. Kettunen.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

E-Governance Evaluation (for project evaluation methods)

Innovations in Governance (for trends in e-governance)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester explores advanced topics in e-governance and the future of public administration.

Smart Governance: Concepts and practices in integrating smart technologies in governance.

Future Trends in E-Governance: Anticipating changes in governance due to emerging technologies.

Capstone Project in E-Governance: A practical project focusing on a real-world e-governance challenge.

Global Perspectives on E-Governance: Examining e-governance practices from around the world.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Smart Governance: A New Era of E-Governance” by David J. T. Whelan.

“E-Governance: Theory and Practice” by A. V. Jayakumar.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Smart Governance (for discussions on smart governance)

Global E-Governance (for international perspectives)

Future Paths

  • E-Governance Consultant: Advising governments on implementing and improving e-governance initiatives.
  • Digital Transformation Manager: Leading digital transformation projects in public administration.
  • Data Analyst in Government: Analyzing data to inform government policies and services.
  • Cybersecurity Specialist: Ensuring the security of government digital platforms.
  • Policy Advisor: Advising on policies related to e-governance and digital services.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in government IT departments or NGOs focused on governance.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in e-governance through events and seminars.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on e-governance trends and regulations through news sources and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on e-governance to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to e-governance for resources and support.
Back

M.Des (Master of Design) Courses

  • Design Theory
  • Design Thinking
  • Visual Design
  • Interaction Design
  • Fashion Design
  • Product Design
  • Design Management
  • Sustainable Design
  • Service Design
  • Design Research
  • Graphic Design
  • Digital Design

Design Theory

This course explores the principles, processes, and practices of design, emphasizing the theoretical frameworks that inform design decisions across various disciplines.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester provides a foundational understanding of design principles and methodologies.

Introduction to Design Theory: Overview of key concepts and historical context in design.

Principles of Design: Exploring fundamental design principles such as balance, contrast, and unity.

Design Process: Understanding the iterative process of design from conception to execution.

Visual Communication: Examining the role of visual elements in conveying messages and ideas.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Basics” by David A. L. Heller.

“The Design of Everyday Things” by Don Norman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Design Basics (for fundamental design concepts)

Visual Communication (for insights on visual elements)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on applied design theories and their implications in real-world scenarios.

Color Theory: Understanding color theory and its impact on design choices.

Typography: Exploring the role of typography in design and communication.

Design Thinking: Introduction to the design thinking methodology and its applications.

Human-Centered Design: Focusing on designing for user needs and experiences.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Interaction of Color” by Josef Albers.

“Thinking, Fast and Slow” by Daniel Kahneman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Color Theory (for understanding color in design)

Typography (for insights into typography)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester delves into advanced design concepts and methodologies.

Design Research Methods: Exploring various research methodologies used in design.

Sustainability in Design: Understanding sustainable practices and materials in design.

Branding and Identity: Examining the role of design in brand development and identity.

Digital Design: Focusing on the principles of designing for digital platforms.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Research: Methods and Perspectives” by Brenda Laurel.

“Sustainable Graphic Design” by Ben Goodman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Design Research (for research methodologies in design)

Sustainable Design (for sustainability in design practices)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester focuses on integrating design theory with practice and future trends in design.

Experimental Design: Encouraging innovative approaches and experimentation in design.

Future Trends in Design: Exploring emerging trends and technologies influencing design.

Capstone Project in Design: A practical project that applies design theory to solve real-world problems.

Ethics in Design: Discussing the ethical implications of design decisions and practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing Design” by Hiroshi Ishii.

“The Ethics of Design” by Gavin Ambrose.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Experimental Design (for innovative design practices)

Future Trends in Design (for emerging trends and technologies)

Future Paths

  • Product Designer: Creating functional and aesthetically pleasing products.
  • User Experience (UX) Designer: Enhancing user satisfaction through design.
  • Brand Designer: Developing brand identities and marketing materials.
  • Design Researcher: Conducting research to inform design decisions.
  • Design Educator: Teaching design principles and practices in academic settings.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in design firms or related industries.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in the design field through events and online platforms.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on design trends and innovations through blogs and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend design workshops to enhance your skills and knowledge.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with design organizations for resources and networking opportunities.
Back

Design Thinking

This course focuses on the Design Thinking methodology, emphasizing problem-solving through a human-centered approach and fostering innovation.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamental concepts of Design Thinking and its applications.

Introduction to Design Thinking: Overview of the Design Thinking process and its importance in innovation.

Empathy Mapping: Techniques for understanding user needs and experiences.

Defining Problems: Learning to articulate problems clearly and effectively.

Ideation Techniques: Exploring various brainstorming and idea generation methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Change by Design” by Tim Brown.

“The Design of Business” by Roger Martin.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Design Thinking (for insights into the Design Thinking process)

Empathy Mapping (for understanding user experiences)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves deeper into the stages of Design Thinking and prototyping.

Prototyping: Techniques for creating and testing prototypes to validate ideas.

User Testing: Conducting tests to gather feedback and insights from users.

Iterative Design: Understanding the importance of iteration in the design process.

Collaboration in Design: Working effectively in teams to enhance creativity and innovation.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Sprint: How to Solve Big Problems and Test New Ideas in Just Five Days” by Jake Knapp.

“The Art of Innovation” by Tom Kelley.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Prototyping (for techniques in prototype development)

User Testing (for insights on user feedback)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on advanced Design Thinking methodologies and their applications in various fields.

Service Design: Exploring the principles of designing services that meet user needs.

Systems Thinking: Understanding the interconnectedness of design solutions within broader systems.

Design Thinking for Social Innovation: Applying Design Thinking principles to address social challenges.

Design Leadership: Developing leadership skills to guide design teams effectively.

Recommended Reference Books:

“This is Service Design Thinking” by Marc Stickdorn.

“The Creative's Guide to Starting a Business” by Harriet Kelsall.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Service Design (for principles of service design)

Social Innovation (for applying design to social issues)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes practical applications of Design Thinking and future trends.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project applying Design Thinking principles to a real-world challenge.

Future Trends in Design Thinking: Exploring emerging trends and technologies in Design Thinking.

Ethics in Design: Discussing ethical considerations in design decisions and practices.

Portfolio Development: Creating a portfolio to showcase design projects and skills.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Thinking: Understanding How Designers Think and Work” by Nigel Cross.

“The Design Thinking Playbook” by Michael Lewrick.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Capstone Project (for insights on completing design projects)

Future Trends in Design Thinking (for exploring future directions)

Future Paths

  • Design Thinking Consultant: Advising organizations on implementing Design Thinking practices.
  • User Experience (UX) Researcher: Conducting research to inform design decisions.
  • Innovation Manager: Leading innovation initiatives within organizations.
  • Service Designer: Designing user-centered services for various industries.
  • Design Educator: Teaching Design Thinking principles and methodologies in academic settings.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in design firms or innovation labs.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in the Design Thinking field through events and online communities.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on Design Thinking trends and methodologies through blogs and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on Design Thinking to enhance your skills.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with design organizations for resources and networking opportunities.
