Visual Design

This course focuses on the principles and techniques of visual design, emphasizing aesthetics, user experience, and communication through design.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamental concepts of visual design, including color theory and typography.

Introduction to Visual Design: Overview of visual design principles and their applications.

Color Theory: Understanding color theory, color palettes, and their emotional impact.

Typography: Learning the principles of typography and its role in design.

Basic Layout Design: Exploring layout techniques for effective visual communication.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Elements of Graphic Design” by Alex W. White.

“Thinking with Type” by Ellen Lupton.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Visual Design Basics (for foundational concepts)

Color Theory Explained (for color fundamentals)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves deeper into design techniques and software tools.

Graphic Design Software: Learning to use popular design software like Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator.

Visual Hierarchy: Understanding the importance of visual hierarchy in design.

Branding and Identity: Exploring the principles of branding and creating visual identities.

Design for Print: Techniques for creating print materials, including brochures and posters.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Graphic Design: The New Basics” by Ellen Lupton and Jennifer Cole Phillips.

“Logo Design Love” by David Airey.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Graphic Design Software Tutorials (for software skills)

Branding Insights (for branding techniques)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on advanced visual design techniques and applications in various media.

Digital Media Design: Creating designs for digital platforms, including websites and mobile apps.

Motion Graphics: Introduction to creating motion graphics and animations.

User Interface (UI) Design: Principles of designing effective user interfaces.

Portfolio Development: Compiling a professional portfolio showcasing design projects.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Don’t Make Me Think” by Steve Krug.

“Motion Graphics Design” by Ian Coyle.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Digital Media Design (for insights into digital design)

Motion Graphics Tutorials (for animation techniques)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes practical applications of visual design and industry trends.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project applying visual design principles to a real-world problem.

Emerging Trends in Design: Exploring the latest trends and technologies in visual design.

Ethics in Design: Discussing ethical considerations in visual design practices.

Client Management: Learning how to manage client relationships and expectations in design projects.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Design of Everyday Things” by Don Norman.

“Designing Brand Identity” by Alina Wheeler.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Capstone Project Insights (for completing design projects)

Emerging Design Trends (for exploring new directions)

Future Paths

  • Graphic Designer: Creating visual content for various media.
  • User Interface (UI) Designer: Designing user-friendly interfaces for applications and websites.
  • Brand Designer: Developing branding materials and visual identities.
  • Motion Graphics Designer: Creating animations and motion graphics for media.
  • Art Director: Leading creative teams and projects in advertising and design.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in design firms or creative agencies.
  • Networking: Connect with design professionals through events and online communities.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on visual design trends and tools through blogs and journals.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend design workshops to enhance your skills and portfolio.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with design organizations for resources and networking opportunities.
Back

Interaction Design

This course focuses on the design of interactive products and systems, emphasizing user experience, usability, and the relationship between users and technology.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational principles of interaction design, covering user-centered design methodologies.

Introduction to Interaction Design: Overview of interaction design principles and practices.

User-Centered Design: Understanding user needs and incorporating them into the design process.

Usability Principles: Exploring key concepts of usability and user experience.

Design Research Methods: Learning techniques for conducting user research and testing.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Design of Everyday Things” by Don Norman.

“Don’t Make Me Think” by Steve Krug.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Introduction to Interaction Design (for foundational concepts)

Usability Principles Explained (for usability fundamentals)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester dives deeper into interaction design techniques and tools.

Prototyping and Wireframing: Learning to create low and high-fidelity prototypes.

Interaction Patterns: Understanding common interaction patterns and their applications.

Information Architecture: Organizing and structuring information for effective navigation.

Visual Design for Interaction: Exploring visual design principles in interactive contexts.

Recommended Reference Books:

“About Face: The Essentials of Interaction Design” by Alan Cooper.

“Designing Interfaces” by Jenifer Tidwell.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Prototyping Techniques (for prototyping skills)

Information Architecture Concepts (for structuring information)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on advanced interaction design topics and user testing methodologies.

User Testing and Evaluation: Techniques for evaluating user interfaces and designs.

Mobile Interaction Design: Designing for mobile platforms and devices.

Human-Computer Interaction (HCI): Exploring the principles of HCI and user behavior.

Accessibility in Design: Understanding the importance of designing for accessibility.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing with the Mind in Mind” by Jeff Johnson.

“A Web for Everyone” by Sarah Horton and Whitney Quesenbery.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

User Testing Techniques (for evaluation methods)

Mobile Interaction Design (for mobile design principles)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes practical applications of interaction design and trends in technology.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project integrating interaction design principles.

Emerging Technologies in Interaction Design: Exploring the impact of new technologies on design.

Design Ethics: Discussing ethical considerations in interaction design.

Career Development in Design: Preparing for a career in interaction design.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing for Emotion” by Aarron Walter.

“The Elements of User Experience” by Jesse James Garrett.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Capstone Project Insights (for completing design projects)

Emerging Technologies in Design (for exploring new trends)

Future Paths

  • Interaction Designer: Designing intuitive interactions between users and products.
  • User Experience (UX) Designer: Focusing on enhancing user satisfaction with products.
  • Usability Analyst: Conducting usability testing and analysis for products.
  • Product Designer: Integrating interaction design with product development.
  • Human-Computer Interaction Researcher: Investigating user interactions and design improvements.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in design firms or tech companies.
  • Networking: Connect with design professionals and attend industry events.
  • Stay Informed: Keep updated on interaction design trends and best practices through blogs and webinars.
  • Participate in Workshops: Attend workshops focused on interaction design and user experience.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with design organizations for resources and networking opportunities.
Back

Fashion Design

This course covers the fundamentals of fashion design, including design concepts, textiles, pattern making, and the fashion industry.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the basics of fashion design, focusing on design principles and sketching techniques.

Introduction to Fashion Design: Overview of the fashion design process and industry.

Fashion Illustration: Learning techniques for sketching and illustrating fashion concepts.

Textiles and Fabrics: Understanding different types of fabrics and their properties.

Fashion History: Exploring the evolution of fashion and major design movements.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Fashion Design Course: Principles, Practice, and Techniques” by Steven Faerm.

“Fashion Sketchbook” by Bina Abling.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Fashion Illustration Techniques (for learning sketching methods)

Fashion History Overview (for insights into fashion evolution)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves deeper into design techniques and the practical aspects of fashion.

Pattern Making: Techniques for creating patterns for garments.

Garment Construction: Learning sewing techniques and garment assembly.

Fashion Marketing: Understanding marketing strategies in the fashion industry.

Color Theory: Exploring color principles and their applications in fashion design.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Patternmaking for Fashion Design” by Helen Joseph-Armstrong.

“Fashion Marketing: Contemporary Issues” by Tony Hines and Margaret Bruce.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Pattern Making Techniques (for practical skills)

Fashion Marketing Strategies (for marketing insights)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on advanced fashion design techniques and industry practices.

Fashion Design Project: A practical project integrating design skills and creativity.

Textile Science: Studying the properties and characteristics of different textiles.

Computer-Aided Design (CAD): Using software tools for fashion design.

Sustainable Fashion: Exploring eco-friendly practices in fashion design.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Fashion Designer Survival Guide” by Mary Gehlhar.

“Sustainable Fashion and Textiles” by Kate Fletcher.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Fashion CAD Techniques (for learning design software)

Sustainable Fashion Practices (for insights on eco-friendly design)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes real-world applications and professional development in fashion.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project showcasing the skills learned throughout the course.

Fashion Branding: Understanding brand development and management in the fashion industry.

Trends and Forecasting: Learning to analyze and predict fashion trends.

Professional Practices: Preparing for a career in fashion design, including portfolio development.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Fashion Branding Unraveled” by Miriam W. M. van der Laan.

“The New Fashion Rulebook” by Elizabeth Walker.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Fashion Branding Strategies (for brand development)

Fashion Trends and Forecasting (for trend analysis)

Future Paths

  • Fashion Designer: Creating original clothing and accessory designs.
  • Textile Designer: Designing textiles and fabrics for fashion applications.
  • Fashion Merchandiser: Managing product selection and sales strategies.
  • Costume Designer: Designing costumes for film, theater, or television.
  • Fashion Stylist: Curating outfits and styling for photoshoots or events.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain hands-on experience through internships with fashion brands or studios.
  • Networking: Attend fashion events and connect with industry professionals.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a strong portfolio showcasing your designs and projects.
  • Stay Updated: Follow fashion trends and industry news through blogs and magazines.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with fashion organizations for resources and support.
Back

Product Design

This course covers the principles of product design, focusing on innovation, user experience, and the development process.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the basics of product design, emphasizing design thinking and user-centered design.

Introduction to Product Design: Overview of the product design process and its importance in various industries.

Design Thinking: Learning the design thinking methodology for innovative problem-solving.

Materials and Manufacturing Processes: Understanding different materials used in product design and their manufacturing methods.

Sketching and Visualization: Techniques for sketching ideas and creating visual representations of designs.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Product Design and Development” by Karl T. Ulrich and Steven D. Eppinger.

“Design Thinking: Understanding How Designers Think and Work” by Nigel Cross.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Product Design Insights (for an overview of the design process)

Design Thinking Methods (for understanding design methodologies)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester delves into advanced design techniques and user experience considerations.

User Experience Design: Focusing on creating user-centered products and improving usability.

Prototyping and Testing: Techniques for building prototypes and conducting user testing.

Computer-Aided Design (CAD): Using software tools for creating digital models of products.

Sustainable Design: Exploring eco-friendly practices in product design and lifecycle analysis.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Design of Everyday Things” by Don Norman.

“Sustainable Design: A Critical Guide” by David Bergman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

User Experience Design Principles (for UX insights)

Prototyping Techniques (for hands-on skills)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester focuses on the integration of design and business strategies.

Design for Manufacturing: Learning how to design products with manufacturing constraints in mind.

Branding and Product Strategy: Understanding how branding influences product design and market positioning.

Design Management: Exploring the role of design management in product development and innovation.

Design Research Methods: Techniques for conducting research to inform design decisions.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Management: Managing Design Strategy, Process and Implementation” by Kathryn Best.

“Branding: In Five and a Half Steps” by Michael Johnson.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Design for Manufacturing Insights (for manufacturing tips)

Branding Strategies (for understanding brand influence)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes real-world applications and capstone projects.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project that integrates all learned skills and knowledge.

Entrepreneurship in Product Design: Exploring how to start and manage a product design business.

Market Trends and Innovation: Understanding current market trends and fostering innovation in design.

Final Portfolio Development: Preparing a professional portfolio to showcase design work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Creative Confidence: Unleashing the Creative Potential Within Us All” by Tom Kelley and David Kelley.

“The Lean Startup” by Eric Ries.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Entrepreneurship Insights (for business strategies)

Market Trends and Innovation (for current trends)

Future Paths

  • Product Designer: Creating innovative products for various industries.
  • UX/UI Designer: Focusing on user experience and interface design.
  • Design Researcher: Conducting research to inform product development and design.
  • Design Manager: Overseeing design projects and teams within organizations.
  • Entrepreneur: Starting and managing a design-focused business or consultancy.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain experience through internships with product design firms or startups.
  • Networking: Attend design events and connect with professionals in the field.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a strong portfolio showcasing your design projects.
  • Stay Informed: Follow design trends and industry news through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to product design for resources and support.
Back

Design Management

This course explores the strategic and operational aspects of managing design processes and teams.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the fundamentals of design management and its role in organizations.

Introduction to Design Management: Overview of design management principles and practices.

Design Process and Methodology: Understanding the design process and various methodologies.

Creativity and Innovation: Exploring techniques to foster creativity and innovation in design teams.

Design Strategy: Learning how to align design efforts with business goals and strategies.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Management: Managing Design Strategy, Process and Implementation” by Kathryn Best.

“The Creative's Guide to Starting a Business” by Harriet Kelsall.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Design Management Insights (for foundational principles)

Creativity and Innovation Techniques (for fostering creativity)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on advanced design management practices and team dynamics.

Team Dynamics in Design: Understanding team dynamics and leadership within design teams.

Design Project Management: Techniques for effectively managing design projects from initiation to completion.

User-Centered Design: Exploring user-centered design principles and their application in projects.

Design Communication: Strategies for effective communication within design teams and with stakeholders.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Management: A Handbook of Issues and Methods” by Brigitte Borja de Mozota.

“The Art of Project Management” by Scott Berkun.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Team Dynamics in Design (for team management insights)

Design Project Management Techniques (for project management skills)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers the intersection of design management with business and marketing strategies.

Design Thinking in Business: Applying design thinking principles to business challenges.

Marketing for Designers: Understanding marketing strategies and their impact on design.

Brand Management: Exploring how design contributes to branding and brand strategy.

Design Metrics and Performance Evaluation: Metrics for evaluating design effectiveness and impact.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing Brand Identity: An Essential Guide for the Whole Branding Team” by Alina Wheeler.

“The Lean Startup” by Eric Ries.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Design Thinking in Business (for application insights)

Brand Management Strategies (for brand strategy insights)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes real-world applications and capstone projects in design management.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project that integrates learned skills in design management.

Sustainable Design Management: Understanding sustainable practices in design management.

Future Trends in Design Management: Exploring emerging trends and their implications for design management.

Final Portfolio Development: Preparing a professional portfolio to showcase design management work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Managing the Design Process: Implementing Design” by Michael M. G. P. Gregor.

“Sustainable Graphic Design: Tools, Methods, and Ideas for a New Era” by Wendy Jedlikowski.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Sustainable Design Management Insights (for sustainability tips)

Future Trends in Design (for emerging trends)

Future Paths

  • Design Manager: Overseeing design projects and teams within organizations.
  • Creative Director: Leading creative efforts in design agencies or corporate settings.
  • Design Strategist: Aligning design initiatives with business objectives.
  • Brand Manager: Managing brand identity and strategy through design.
  • Consultant: Providing expertise in design management to organizations.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain experience through internships with design firms or creative agencies.
  • Networking: Attend design and industry events to connect with professionals.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a strong portfolio showcasing your design management projects.
  • Stay Informed: Follow industry trends and best practices through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with design management organizations for resources and support.
Back

Sustainable Design

This course focuses on environmentally responsible design practices that meet present needs without compromising future generations.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the principles of sustainability and their application in design.

Introduction to Sustainable Design: Overview of sustainable design principles and philosophies.

Eco-Friendly Materials: Exploring sustainable materials and their properties.

Life Cycle Assessment: Understanding the life cycle of products and their environmental impact.

Design for Environment (DfE): Techniques to design products with minimal environmental impact.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Sustainable Design: A Critical Guide” by David Bergman.

“The Natural Step for Communities: How to Implement Sustainability” by Sarah James and Danica Hennin.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Sustainable Design Basics (for foundational principles)

Eco-Friendly Materials Insights (for material properties)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on design strategies that promote sustainability.

Green Building Design: Principles and practices for sustainable architecture and construction.

Urban Sustainability: Examining sustainable practices in urban planning and design.

Product Design for Sustainability: Designing products with a focus on sustainability.

Sustainable Fashion Design: Exploring sustainable practices in the fashion industry.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Green Building and LEED Core Concepts Guide” by the U.S. Green Building Council.

“Fashion and Sustainability: Design for Change” by Kate Fletcher and Lynda Grose.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Green Building Design (for architectural insights)

Urban Sustainability Practices (for urban planning tips)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers the integration of sustainability in design processes and business models.

Sustainable Design Strategies: Techniques for integrating sustainability into design processes.

Design and Social Responsibility: Understanding the social impact of design decisions.

Sustainable Marketing: Exploring marketing strategies for sustainable products.

Innovation in Sustainable Design: Fostering innovation in sustainable design practices.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Sustainable Design Handbook” by Michelle E. Moore.

“Design and Social Responsibility” by Tony Fry.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Sustainable Design Strategies (for process integration)

Innovation in Sustainability (for fostering innovation)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes hands-on projects and the application of sustainable design principles.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project demonstrating sustainable design principles.

Policy and Regulation in Sustainable Design: Understanding regulations impacting sustainable design.

Future Trends in Sustainable Design: Exploring emerging trends and their implications for design.

Portfolio Development: Preparing a professional portfolio to showcase sustainable design work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design for Sustainability: A Sourcebook of Integrated, Eco-Logical Solutions” by Janis Birkeland.

“The Future of Sustainable Design” by Andrew H. Cohen.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Future of Sustainable Design (for emerging trends)

Policy and Regulation Insights (for regulatory understanding)

Future Paths

  • Sustainable Design Consultant: Advising organizations on sustainable design practices.
  • Green Building Designer: Specializing in sustainable architecture and construction.
  • Product Designer: Focusing on eco-friendly and sustainable product design.
  • Sustainability Manager: Overseeing sustainability initiatives within organizations.
  • Environmental Policy Advocate: Working on policy development related to sustainable design.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain experience through internships with sustainable design firms.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in sustainable design through events and seminars.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a strong portfolio showcasing your sustainable design projects.
  • Stay Informed: Follow industry trends and best practices through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to sustainable design for resources and support.
Back

Service Design

This course focuses on designing and optimizing services to enhance user experience and operational efficiency.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts and methodologies of service design.

Introduction to Service Design: Overview of service design principles and methodologies.

User-Centered Design: Techniques for designing services based on user needs and behaviors.

Service Blueprinting: Learning to create blueprints for visualizing service processes.

Research Methods in Service Design: Exploring qualitative and quantitative research methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

“This is Service Design Thinking” by Marc Stickdorn and Jakob Schneider.

“Service Design: From Insight to Implementation” by Andy Polaine, Lavrans Løvlie, and Ben Reason.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Service Design Channel (for foundational principles)

User-Centered Design Insights (for user-centered methodologies)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on practical applications and tools for service design.

Prototyping and Testing Services: Techniques for creating and testing service prototypes.

Service Design Tools and Techniques: Exploring various tools used in service design.

Service Innovation: Strategies for innovating and improving existing services.

Designing Service Experiences: Focus on creating memorable customer experiences.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Service Design for Business” by Ben Reason, Lavrans Løvlie, and Kim E. H. Jørgensen.

“The Service Innovation Handbook” by Lucy Kimbell.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Service Design Tools (for practical applications)

Service Innovation (for innovation strategies)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers advanced topics in service design and management.

Strategic Service Design: Understanding the strategic aspects of designing services.

Service Operations Management: Managing service delivery and operations effectively.

Customer Journey Mapping: Techniques for mapping and improving the customer journey.

Digital Service Design: Designing services in the digital environment.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Service Design Playbook” by Patrick M. van D. H. Berkhout.

“Designing Services That Deliver” by James C. Spohrer.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Customer Journey Mapping Insights (for mapping techniques)

Digital Service Design (for digital design principles)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes hands-on projects and real-world applications of service design.

Capstone Project: A comprehensive project showcasing service design skills.

Ethics and Sustainability in Service Design: Exploring ethical considerations in service design.

Future Trends in Service Design: Understanding emerging trends and technologies.

Portfolio Development: Creating a professional portfolio to showcase service design work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Service Design: 2nd Edition” by Andy Polaine, Lavrans Løvlie, and Ben Reason.

“This is Service Design Doing” by Stickdorn, Lawrence, and Schneider.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Future of Service Design (for emerging trends)

Service Design Portfolio Tips (for portfolio development)

Future Paths

  • Service Designer: Specializing in designing and improving service experiences.
  • User Experience (UX) Designer: Focusing on user-centered design for services.
  • Customer Experience Manager: Overseeing customer interactions and experiences.
  • Service Innovation Consultant: Advising organizations on service innovation strategies.
  • Operations Manager: Managing service delivery and operations.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain experience through internships in service design roles.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in service design through events and seminars.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a portfolio showcasing service design projects and processes.
  • Stay Informed: Follow industry trends and best practices through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to service design for resources and support.
Back

Design Research

This course focuses on methodologies and practices for conducting effective research in design.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts and methodologies of design research.

Introduction to Design Research: Overview of research principles and methodologies in design.

Qualitative Research Methods: Techniques for gathering qualitative data through interviews and observations.

Quantitative Research Methods: Learning to use surveys and statistical analysis for data collection.

User-Centered Research: Focus on understanding user needs and behaviors through research.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Design Research: Methods and Perspectives” by Brenda Laurel.

“The Design of Everyday Things” by Don Norman.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Design Research Channel (for foundational principles)

User Research Methods (for qualitative techniques)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on advanced research methodologies and analysis techniques.

Mixed Methods Research: Combining qualitative and quantitative research approaches.

Data Analysis Techniques: Exploring tools for analyzing qualitative and quantitative data.

Research Ethics: Understanding ethical considerations in design research.

Participatory Design: Involving users in the design process through research activities.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Research Design: Qualitative, Quantitative, and Mixed Methods Approaches” by John W. Creswell.

“Design Research: A Sociological Perspective” by Jeffrey Bardzell and Shaowen Bardzell.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Mixed Methods Research (for advanced methodologies)

Data Analysis Techniques (for analysis tools)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers applied research in real-world design contexts.

Case Studies in Design Research: Analyzing successful research projects in design.

Contextual Inquiry: Learning to conduct in-depth investigations into user contexts.

Design Evaluation Methods: Techniques for evaluating design outcomes based on research.

Design Thinking and Research: Integrating design thinking principles with research methods.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Field Study Handbook” by John S. Brown and R. Brian Haynes.

“Design Research for Architects” by Eileen W. H. Tsang.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Case Studies in Design (for real-world applications)

Contextual Inquiry Insights (for contextual investigations)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes independent research projects and synthesizing learning.

Capstone Research Project: Conducting a comprehensive research project in design.

Presenting Research Findings: Techniques for effectively communicating research results.

Future Trends in Design Research: Exploring emerging trends and technologies in the field.

Portfolio Development: Creating a professional portfolio showcasing research work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Researching Design Learning” by Susan M. D. G. DiMarco.

“The Craft of Research” by Wayne C. Booth, Gregory G. Colomb, and Joseph M. Williams.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Research Findings (for presentation techniques)

Future Trends in Design (for emerging trends)

Future Paths

  • Design Researcher: Conducting research to inform design processes and decisions.
  • User Experience Researcher: Focusing on understanding user needs through research.
  • Product Designer: Applying research findings to create user-centered products.
  • Design Strategist: Using research to develop strategic design initiatives.
  • Consultant in Design Research: Advising organizations on effective research methodologies.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in design research roles.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in design research through events and seminars.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a portfolio showcasing your research projects and methodologies.
  • Stay Informed: Follow industry trends and best practices through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to design research for resources and support.
Back

Graphic Design

This course explores the principles, tools, and practices of graphic design.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational concepts and techniques of graphic design.

Introduction to Graphic Design: Overview of design principles, elements, and visual communication.

Typography: Study of typefaces, fonts, and the art of arranging text effectively.

Color Theory: Understanding color principles and their application in design.

Basic Design Software: Introduction to design software like Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Graphic Design: A New History” by Stephen J. Eskilson.

“Thinking with Type” by Ellen Lupton.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Graphic Design Basics (for foundational concepts)

Typography and Design (for typography insights)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on advanced techniques and the application of graphic design.

Digital Illustration: Techniques for creating illustrations using digital tools.

Layout and Composition: Principles of arranging visual elements effectively.

Branding and Identity Design: Creating visual identities for brands and businesses.

Design for Print: Exploring print production processes and design considerations.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Logo Design Love” by David Airey.

“The Elements of Graphic Design” by Alex W. White.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Digital Illustration Techniques (for advanced illustration)

Branding and Identity (for branding insights)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers applied design projects and real-world applications.

Web Design Basics: Introduction to designing for web and digital interfaces.

Motion Graphics: Basics of creating animated graphics and video.

User Experience (UX) Design: Understanding user-centered design principles.

Portfolio Development: Creating a professional portfolio showcasing design work.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Don't Make Me Think” by Steve Krug.

“The Graphic Design Exercise Book” by Steven Heller and Karen Pomeroy.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Web Design Basics (for web design fundamentals)

Motion Graphics Tutorials (for animation skills)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes independent design projects and synthesizing learning.

Capstone Graphic Design Project: Conducting a comprehensive design project.

Design Trends and Innovations: Exploring current trends in graphic design.

Design Critique and Feedback: Techniques for giving and receiving design feedback.

Professional Practices in Design: Preparing for a career in graphic design.

Recommended Reference Books:

“The Designer's Guide to Marketing and Pricing” by Ilise Benun.

“Steal Like an Artist” by Austin Kleon.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Graphic Design Trends (for current trends)

Design Critique Insights (for critique techniques)

Future Paths

  • Graphic Designer: Creating visual content for various media and platforms.
  • Branding Specialist: Developing brand identities and strategies.
  • Web Designer: Designing websites and user interfaces.
  • Illustrator: Producing custom illustrations for publications and media.
  • Motion Graphic Artist: Creating animated graphics for video and digital content.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in graphic design studios.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in graphic design through events and online communities.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a diverse portfolio showcasing your design projects.
  • Stay Informed: Follow design trends and innovations through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to graphic design for resources and support.
Back

Digital Design

This course focuses on the principles, tools, and techniques of digital design across various media.

Semester 1

Semester 1 Subjects:

The first semester introduces the foundational aspects of digital design.

Introduction to Digital Design: Overview of digital design concepts, principles, and processes.

Graphic Design Basics: Understanding the fundamentals of visual communication and graphic design.

Digital Imaging: Techniques for creating and manipulating digital images using software tools.

Typography in Digital Media: Exploring typefaces, font usage, and their application in digital design.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Digital Design Essentials” by Rajesh A. Babu.

“The Non-Designer’s Design Book” by Robin Williams.

YouTube Channels for Semester 1 Subjects:

Digital Design Basics (for foundational concepts)

Digital Imaging Techniques (for image editing skills)

Semester 2

Semester 2 Subjects:

The second semester focuses on advanced tools and applications in digital design.

Web Design Fundamentals: Introduction to designing for web interfaces and user experience.

User Interface (UI) Design: Principles and techniques for creating intuitive user interfaces.

Motion Graphics: Basics of creating animations and motion graphics for digital media.

Color Theory for Digital Design: Understanding color application and its psychological effects.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing for the Web” by Mark Boulton.

“The Animator's Survival Kit” by Richard Williams.

YouTube Channels for Semester 2 Subjects:

Web Design Fundamentals (for web design basics)

Motion Graphics Tutorials (for animation skills)

Semester 3

Semester 3 Subjects:

The third semester covers practical design projects and applied techniques.

Interactive Design: Principles of designing interactive digital experiences.

Digital Illustration: Techniques for creating illustrations using digital tools and software.

Responsive Web Design: Creating designs that adapt to various screen sizes and devices.

Portfolio Development: Building a professional portfolio to showcase design projects.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Responsive Web Design” by Ethan Marcotte.

“Illustration That Works” by Greg M. Manley.

YouTube Channels for Semester 3 Subjects:

Interactive Design Insights (for interactive design techniques)

Digital Illustration Techniques (for advanced illustration)

Semester 4

Semester 4 Subjects:

The final semester emphasizes independent design projects and synthesizing learning.

Capstone Digital Design Project: Conducting a comprehensive design project integrating learned skills.

Trends in Digital Design: Exploring current trends, tools, and innovations in digital design.

Design Critique: Techniques for providing and receiving constructive feedback on design work.

Professional Practices in Digital Design: Preparing for a career in digital design, including branding and marketing.

Recommended Reference Books:

“Designing Brand Identity” by Alina Wheeler.

“The Creative's Guide to Starting a Business” by Harriet Kelsall.

YouTube Channels for Semester 4 Subjects:

Digital Design Trends (for current trends)

Design Critique Insights (for critique techniques)

Future Paths

  • Digital Designer: Creating visual content for digital platforms and media.
  • User Experience (UX) Designer: Focusing on enhancing user satisfaction through usability.
  • Web Designer: Designing and developing websites and digital interfaces.
  • Motion Graphics Designer: Producing animated content for advertisements and videos.
  • Interactive Media Designer: Developing interactive experiences and applications.

Preparation Tips

  • Internships: Gain practical experience through internships in digital design firms.
  • Networking: Connect with professionals in digital design through events and online communities.
  • Portfolio Development: Create a diverse portfolio showcasing your digital design projects.
  • Stay Informed: Follow digital design trends and innovations through blogs and publications.
  • Join Professional Associations: Engage with organizations related to digital design for resources and support.
Back
